Peter I
History

Peter was born the fourth son of the Tsar Alexey I. After the death of his father and older brother, at the age of 10 he became co-tsar with his sickly half-brother, Ivan, under the regency of their sister Sophia Alexeevna. Apparently Peter was quite the terror in his teens. He had utter contempt for religious and political ceremony, combined with almost limitless energy and a capacity for alcohol. At 17 he had the regent (his elder sister) arrested on charges of conspiring against him and had her locked in a convent, where she would stay for the rest of her life. He took total control of the empire, his brother Ivan no more than a figurehead.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In addition to drinking, carousing, and political intrigue, young Peter was also fascinated by military affairs. In 1695, he ordered the army to move against the Turks. Astonishingly, he didn't command his forces in the field, instead choosing to act as an lowly artilleryman. The Russian forces emerged victorious and within a year had captured the vital port of Azov.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Several years later, Peter set off on a tour of Europe. He spent 16 months traveling incognito through Germany, Holland, England and Austria, at one time working as a shipwright in England and Holland. Peter learned a lot during his trip, and he later hired many western craftsmen, engineers, soldiers, sailors, architects and artists to help modernize Russia. Once home, Peter adopted many European customs, including a mandate that beards were to be shaved off at court, which was a great controversy that nearly caused a revolt with the Boyars.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Despite his love of European culture, Peter remained a drunken, overbearing bully, whose practical jokes stopped just short of outright torture. (Or perhaps went a little over the line.) Foreign observers noted with horror that at a state dinner Peter had one of his cronies hold another tight, pinning his arms and forcing his mouth open. The victim was known to hate salads and especially vinegar; Peter jammed salad into his mouth and down his throat and then poured vinegar up his nose until it bled.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Peter liked to force his guests - including foreign diplomats - to drink until they passed out, then wake them up an hour later and force them to drink more. He once woke a group of extremely inebriated men up in the middle of the night, gave them axes and demanded that they help him cut down trees to make a path to the seashore.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In 1700 Russia went to war against Sweden. But, Gustavus Aldolphus, the Swedish King, proved more cunning to him, striking Peter's army before it was prepared, capturing much of the Russian artillery in the process. In response Peter demanded that all of the bells in Moscow (including church bells) be melted down to make cannons. He also confiscated church treasure to fuel the war effort. The war dragged on, but in 1709 the Swedish forces were decisively defeated, and Russia gained parts of Finland, Estonia, and Latvia.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Peter's home life did not go particularly well. In 1698 his wife was implicated in a plot to overthrow him; he divorced her and sent her off to yet another convent. In 1712 he married his mistress, Martha Skavronsky, a former Lithuanian servant and previously the mistress of a bevey of other Russian nobles. She gave him four children. In 1718 the tsar's oldest son Alexey was imprisoned for suspected treason and died under torture.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Upon his death Peter was buried in Saint Petersburg, the vital port and Russian capital, which he established in 1703, in the Peter and Paul Cathedral. Presumably under the heaviest rock they could find.
Peter I
Leader of Russia
Emperor of All Russia

Exciting days await Russia, for upon her throne lies your imperial gaze, wise and excellent Peter the Great. Ascending to the Tsarist Kingdom at the age of ten, you beheld a vision of an empire that was both great and powerful, and which would transform the archaic and obsolete Motherland into a nation of enlightenment. Declaring yourself emperor in 1721, you embarked upon sweeping reformations inspired by the meritocratic and rationalist ideals of the West. Your designs to empower the navy, and to extend Russia's borders toward Scandinavia, would see you clash with the Swedish King Charles XII in the Great Northern War. But from it you would eventually arise victorious, and with it you would seize the opportunity to lay the foundation of your most lasting legacy: the city of Saint Petersburg.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Noble emperor, your life has been one devoted to the elevation of Russia to legendary heights of power and culture, and once more you are called to meet that duty. Can you expand your frontiers to the farthest reaches of this earth? Can you embolden the Russian people with a wealth of culture and excellence? Can you build a civilisation that can stand the test of time?

Welcome, welcome! I am the most excellent Peter the Great, Emperor of all Russia, and sovereign prince of lands here and there. I'm sure you have much to share with me, and I am simply thrilled to hear it all.
Ah-hah! A stranger arrives in my court. Welcome! I am Peter, Emperor of Russia, and tamer of this ferocious land. I admire the cleanliness of your teeth. Mind if I take a closer look?
What a sorry day this is for Russia; to witness my defeat! I weep that I could not bring to myself the reforms that I have brought unto my people.
I bow to you, my worthy adversary. Only a man blessed by God could have done battle with Russia and come away victorious.
What is it this time? Don't you have someone else to bother?
Why are you wasting my time? You haven't even changed your offer, you idiot.
The unpleasant one shows his face.
What can I, by the Grace of God, Peter of Russia, do for you this day? Hm?
The mercy of Peter the Great is legendary. Not today, though, because I'm looking forward to your being crushed into the pages of history.
I wish you God speed in your war, my friend. Now what can I do for you?
Your military advances have caused quite a stir in my court. I have told my advisors that it is harmless fun; but I am not so sure for how long I can trust my own words.
Your purchase of nearby land is getting on my nerves. I won't tolerate it forever, you know?
So this is how it's going to be? You're going to buy lands that I consider to be mine, and you're going to continue to make me positively livid as a consequence. How unexcellent of you.
The spread of your cities and people is like a plague infecting the land. I look forward to the day I don't have to see it any more.
While I have this opportunity, I should mention that your expansion has worried several of my officials. I hope that this does not cause any problems in the future. What would you like to discuss?
I have heard much of your disciplined military. Are there are open positions for me, do you think?
Your economy is famous for its prosperity. I wish that you would share with me your secrets.
The lowly prince that walks into my court with the height of a king. Turn your tail, for you may not address this emperor until you are my equal. So basically never.
Your army is quite small. How do you expect to defend yourself when I march on your capital? Oh! I didn't say that...
You clearly have no interest in peace, you unrefined warmonger. So much war is bad for your skin, you know, and it shows.
It would be much too undignified to declare such a thing with you at this time.

There's little use for you being around. Others should be told of this truth, and encouraged to act accordingly.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])

Never have I known a most unrefined and unexcellent brute as yourself. The world must be told of your misdeeds.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
Know that Russia will never forget this indecency, you damnable idiot.
I am aghast. You're denouncing me?
I'm pleased that you've declared friendship with {1_CivName}. Isn't it just excellent when we all get along?
{1_CivName} deserves no courtesy from you.
You are a fool for denouncing {1_CivName}? I have had excellent dealings with them; I believe you have made a careless decision. I think you might need to be patched.
{1_CivName} deserves every bit of hate they can get. I am glad you feel the same.
I noticed that you have declared your friendship with {1_CivName}. Well, if you think they're to be trusted, then you have Russia's support.
Wonderful, you and {1_CivName} will make a most unexcellent partnership.
I, too, believe that {1_CivName} is a joke of an empire. Perhaps the combination of our denouncements will make them weep.
{1_PlayerName:textkey} has caused much misery to my people and should be dealt with. Don't you agree?
{1_PlayerName:textkey} is a menace to this world. They also have some nice titles. I pledge that we take some for ourselves.
If you're quite finished with your lunch, it is time for war against {1_PlayerName:textkey}.
I propose that we tell the world of our friendship. Let them envy this bond with mighty Russia!
I think we could benefit from a friendship, don't you?
It's come to my attention that you have a large number of Units near my borders. I request that you move them elsewhere to avoid causing undue distress to my citizens.
I'm growing very concerned about the rate at which you think you can buy lands that belong to me. Stop it, will you.
So this is how it's going to be? You're going to buy lands that I consider to be mine, and you're going to continue to make me positively livid as a consequence. How unexcellent of you.
You believe that you can out-expand me? Hah! Let us embark upon a battle to cover this earth with our legacies then.
Your expansion efforts are an insult. Know that there will be consequences for this.
Ah, excellent! I was wondering where they'd gotten to; I'd sent them out for tea hours ago! You have my thanks.
I'm not a fan of you or your empire. I think it's quite backwards. I just thought I'd let you know; so maybe you'd get the sense to abdicate or something.
Ah, it's always nice to see my favorite city-state again.
I'm really getting tired of seeing your face. My hope is that one day you'll just go away or something.
Ah, it's you. My apologies. Sometimes I get you mixed up with the barbarians I have to swat from time to time.
You barely have an army at all! Better not let someone like me know. Oh! Too late, hehe.
With an army so weak it's a surprise your empire hasn't succumb to a barbarian invasion.
It shows just how pathetic you are that you must pick on the innocent; depriving me of the opportunity.
I can hear your people wailing in sorrow all the way over in my empire. If you don't do something soon they might just pack up and find a real civilization to live in.
Your people are so unhappy. You must be quite the horrible person. Tell them from me that they are more than welcome to join a real civilization.
Your empire is so tiny I can barely see it on a map! It's really quite pitiful, you know.
Travelers have told us that your empire's economy is in pretty sad shape. If you beg a little I might give you a hand. Okay, actually I won't.
Your empire is the most uncultured thing that I have ever seen. Perhaps I should take over? I would certainly do a better job than you.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} announces to the world that it is now protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}. Attacking the City-State will greatly damage relations and may lead to war.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} has taken back its guarantee of protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}.
Absolutely not. I am by God the sovereign of these lands and I will uphold this as a devotion unto His will.
Fine, fine. Be unexcellent then.
This trade would be quite excellent, don't you agree?
I want to learn so very much of your ways. Please, let us not impede progress by these petty borders.
In order for the Russian people to become more like you, I would very much like this agreement to go through.
Apparently, your military advisor is an idiot, for he did not advise you that attacking the gargantuan Russian Empire was a death sentence.
You have asked for the wrath of hell, and by God I shall deliver.
You have asked for the wrath of hell, and by God I shall deliver.
You have asked for the wrath of hell, and by God I shall deliver.
Apparently, your military advisor is an idiot, for he did not advise you that attacking the gargantuan Russian Empire was a death sentence.
Apparently, your military advisor is an idiot, for he did not advise you that attacking the gargantuan Russian Empire was a death sentence.
I had thought I'd already conquered you, but my advisors told me otherwise. So, you see, I must remedy that. It's nothing personal.
I, Peter the Great, by the grace of God, declare you the future vassal of my empire.
Your empire might now make for a nice governorate, don't you think?
I had thought I'd already conquered you, but my advisors told me otherwise. So, you see, I must remedy that. It's nothing personal.
Russia has become such an epitome of culture and excellence. It is my duty to God to bring that to the savages of this earth, you see.
I'll remind my historians to be kind of you whence you have been defeated, and your empire is but another part of my excellent design.
I was awaiting this opportunity. I cannot be ascribed fault for your weakness as a leader.
I refuse to forfeit my imperial crown. Your conquest will prove my right to be emperor of all Russia.
This is not a personal matter, my friend. Please forgive me, but my people and my empire must come first.
It's much too soon for peace. I have a nobility to impress and a people to dignify.
What a shame you couldn't be reasoned with. Now I have to plan on crushing you; oh well.
This is terribly uncivil of you.
Excellent. I'm glad you saw better sense than to upset me.
Petrine Reformation

Research technologies already discovered by another Civilization 25% faster. This bonus increases if you have a Declaration of Friendship with that Civilization. Each new city increases Social Policy [ICON_CULTURE] Culture costs by 50% less.
Two-Decker

A two-decker is a sail warship which carried her guns on two fully armed decks. Usually additional guns were carried on the upper works (forecastle and quarterdeck), but this was not a continuous battery, so were not counted. Two-deckers ranged all the way from the small 40-gun Fifth rate up to 80- or even 90-gun ships, with the third-rate or "seventy-four" being the archetype.

Cheap Ranaissance Era naval ranged unit that starts with additional experience for every Declaration of Friendship that you have and specializes in defeating land units. Does not require a source of [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron to be built. Only Peter's Russia may build it.

The Two-Decker is a unique unit for Peter's Russia, replacing the Frigate. Weaker but cheaper than the Frigate, the Two-Decker receives a +25% Combat Bonus against land units and starts with an additional 10 XP for every Declaration of Friendship that you have. Unlike the Frigate, the Two-Decker does not require a source of [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron to be built.
Two Decker
+25% Combat Bonus against land units.
Second Hand
Starts with an additional 10 XP for every Declaration of Friendship that you have.

+2 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness when garrisoned. +15 XP for all military units built in this city. Reduces [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_GOLD] Gold costs for acquiring new tiles by 25% (50% when garrisoned). Requires no [ICON_GOLD] Gold maintenance.

The Krepost is the unique building for Peter's Russia, replacing the Barracks. The Krepost increases this city's [ICON_STRENGTH] Defense Strength by 5 and increases the civilization's [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness when garrisoned. The Krepost increases this city's [ICON_CULTURE] Cultural border growth and reduces the cost of purchasing tiles with [ICON_GOLD] Gold, especially when garrisoned. The Krepost has no maintenance cost.
+2 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness. Reduces [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and [ICON_GOLD] Gold costs for acquiring new tiles by 25%.

Constantinople
Each worked Strategic Resource provides +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horse, [ICON_RES_IRON] Iron and [ICON_RES_URANIUM] Uranium Resources provide double the quantity.
Banya

Banya or banja can refer to a number of types of steam baths popular in Eastern Europe. In Russia, it refers to a particular local type of sauna. A mention of the banya is found in the Radzivill Chronicle in the story of Princess Olga's revenge for the murder of her husband, Prince Igor, by the Slavic tribe of Drevlians in 945 AD. The leader of the Drevlians had hopes of marrying the widow Olga and sent messengers to discuss the idea. "When the Drevlians arrived, Olga commanded that a bath should be made ready for them and said, 'Wash yourselves and come to me.' The bath-house was heated and the unsuspecting Drevlians entered and began to wash themselves. Olga's men closed the bath-house behind them and Olga gave orders to set it on fire from the doors, so that the Drevlians were all burned to death."
+25% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People generation in this city. Military land units built in this city heal at double the rate. Reduces [ICON_GOLD] Gold costs for purchasing tiles in this city by 25%.

The Banya is the unique building for for Catherine's Russia, replacing the Garden. The Banya increases the civilization's [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness as well as the speed at which Great People are generated in this city. The Banya reduces the cost of purchasing tiles with [ICON_GOLD] Gold and allows military land units built in this city to heal at double the rate. The Banya does not require this city to be next to a River or Lake to be built.
Banya
Heals at double the rate.
Fast Industrial Era mounted unit that ignores enemy zones of control and specializes in defeating wounded units. Only Catherine's Russia may build it.

The Cossack is the unique unit for Catherine's Russia, replacing the Cavalry. Faster than the Cavalry, the Cossack receives a +33% Attack Bonus against wounded units and ignores enemy zones of control.
Ignores Zones of Control
Ignores enemy zones of control.
